first_reasoning: We should allocate the full $10 million to the Consumer Products Division because its stronger ten-year sales growth indicates higher latent market demand that carefully targeted R&D can unlock. By supplementing the existing team with outside experts, building in rapid consumer feedback loops, running a controlled pilot launch, and enforcing clear stage-gate metrics tied to prototypes, pilot sales, and cost targets, we can maximize the odds of a meaningful sales rebound and margin recovery. This disciplined approach offers a more attractive risk-reward profile than investing in Industrial, where growth has largely plateaued.
second_reasoning: We recommend allocating the full available funding to the Consumer Products Division because its stronger ten‐year sales growth and latent market demand give a superior risk‐reward profile. With external expertise, rapid market feedback, a controlled pilot rollout, and clear stage‐gate metrics in place, the Consumer division is best positioned to turn R&D investment into meaningful sales and margin gains, whereas Industrial’s growth runway appears more limited.
